title: Sequences, Series & Introduction to Limits
description: Arithmetic and geometric sequences and series, sigma notation, convergence of infinite geometric series, intuitive and algebraic limits, continuity, and limits at infinity — bridging Pre-Calculus to Calculus.
goals: Find the nth term and partial sums of arithmetic sequences; model linear growth.
Find the nth term, partial sums, and infinite sums of geometric sequences; model exponential growth/decay.
Use sigma notation to express and evaluate finite and infinite series.
Evaluate limits intuitively from tables, graphs, and numerical patterns.
Evaluate limits algebraically using direct substitution, factoring, rationalizing, and simplification.
Determine continuity at a point; evaluate one-sided limits and limits at infinity.
instructionalStrategy: Gradual release model; AI-led instruction using scaffold as scope
Connect sequences/series to function behavior and limits conceptually
Spiral prior skills: polynomial/rational simplification, radical expressions

scaffold.title: Sequences: Arithmetic & Geometric
scaffold.content: A sequence is an ordered list of numbers. Arithmetic sequences have a constant difference; geometric sequences have a constant ratio.
keyPoints: Arithmetic: aₙ = a₁ + (n-1)d. Common difference d = aₙ₊₁ - aₙ.
Arithmetic partial sum: Sₙ = n/2·(a₁ + aₙ) = n/2·(2a₁ + (n-1)d).
Geometric: aₙ = a₁·rⁿ⁻¹. Common ratio r = aₙ₊₁/aₙ.
Geometric partial sum: Sₙ = a₁(1-rⁿ)/(1-r) for r ≠ 1.
Infinite geometric series: S = a₁/(1-r) converges only if |r| < 1.
Recursive vs. explicit formulas: recursive defines each term from previous; explicit gives nth term directly.

examples.problem: An arithmetic sequence has a₃ = 11 and a₈ = 31. Find: (a) d and a₁, (b) a₂₀, (c) S₂₀.
A geometric sequence has a₁ = 6 and r = 1/3. Find: (a) a₅, (b) S₆, (c) S (infinite sum).
Write the repeating decimal 0.454545... as a fraction using an infinite geometric series.

scaffold.title: Series & Sigma Notation
scaffold.content: A series is the sum of terms of a sequence. Sigma notation Σ provides a compact way to express sums.
keyPoints: Sigma notation: Σₖ₌₁ⁿ aₖ = a₁ + a₂ + ··· + aₙ.
Index of summation (k), lower limit, upper limit.
Properties: Σ(aₖ + bₖ) = Σaₖ + Σbₖ; Σ(caₖ) = cΣaₖ.
Useful formulas: Σk = n(n+1)/2, Σk² = n(n+1)(2n+1)/6, Σk³ = [n(n+1)/2]².
Telescoping series: most terms cancel, leaving first and last.
Partial sums Sₙ reveal convergence behavior.

problems.problem: Find the sum of the first 30 terms of the arithmetic sequence 7, 12, 17, 22, ...
Determine whether the infinite geometric series 12 - 8 + 16/3 - 32/9 + ··· converges. If so, find the sum.

scaffold.title: Introduction to Limits
scaffold.content: The limit of f(x) as x approaches c is the value that f(x) gets arbitrarily close to, regardless of whether f(c) exists or equals the limit.
keyPoints: Notation: lim(x→c) f(x) = L means f(x) → L as x → c.
A limit exists if and only if both one-sided limits exist and are equal.
Left-hand limit: lim(x→c⁻) f(x). Right-hand limit: lim(x→c⁺) f(x).
The limit can exist even if f(c) is undefined (e.g., removable discontinuity).
Estimate limits from tables by evaluating f(x) for x-values approaching c from both sides.
Estimate limits from graphs by tracing the curve toward x = c from both directions.

examples.problem: Use a table to estimate lim(x→2) (x²-4)/(x-2).

examples.solution: For x→0⁺: |x|/x = x/x = 1. For x→0⁻: |x|/x = -x/x = -1. Left ≠ Right: 1 ≠ -1. The limit does not exist.

examples.problem: Given the piecewise function f(x) = {x+1 if x<3; 5 if x=3; 2x-2 if x>3}, find lim(x→3) f(x).
examples.solution: lim(x→3⁻) f(x) = lim(x→3⁻)(x+1) = 4. lim(x→3⁺) f(x) = lim(x→3⁺)(2x-2) = 4. Both sides equal 4, so lim(x→3) f(x) = 4. (Note: f(3)=5≠4, so there's a removable discontinuity.)

scaffold.title: Algebraic Limit Techniques
scaffold.content: When direct substitution yields an indeterminate form (0/0), algebraic manipulation can resolve the limit.
keyPoints: Direct substitution: if f(c) is defined and f is continuous, lim(x→c) f(x) = f(c).
Indeterminate form 0/0: factor, cancel, then re-evaluate.
Rationalizing: multiply by conjugate to eliminate radicals.
Complex fractions: simplify by finding common denominator.
Limit laws: sum, product, quotient, constant multiple, power rules.
Special limit: lim(x→0) sin(x)/x = 1.

examples.solution: Direct sub: 0/0 (indeterminate). Factor: (x²-9)/(x-3) = (x-3)(x+3)/(x-3) = x+3 for x≠3. lim(x→3)(x+3) = 6.

scaffold.title: Continuity & Limits at Infinity
scaffold.content: A function is continuous at c if lim(x→c) f(x) = f(c). Limits at infinity describe end behavior.
keyPoints: Continuous at c requires: (1) f(c) exists, (2) lim(x→c) f(x) exists, (3) lim(x→c) f(x) = f(c).
Types of discontinuity: removable (hole), jump, infinite (vertical asymptote).
Polynomials are continuous everywhere. Rational functions are continuous on their domain.
Limits at infinity: lim(x→∞) 1/xⁿ = 0 for n > 0.
Rational functions: divide by highest power of x. Compare degrees of numerator and denominator.
Horizontal asymptotes: deg(num) < deg(den) → HA y=0; equal degrees → HA y = leading coeff ratio; deg(num) > deg(den) → no HA.

scaffold.title: Continuity & Limits at Infinity — Worked Examples

examples.problem: Determine if f(x) = (x²-1)/(x-1) is continuous at x=1. If not, classify the discontinuity.
examples.solution: f(1) is undefined (0/0). lim(x→1) (x²-1)/(x-1) = lim(x→1)(x+1) = 2. The limit exists but f(1) doesn't. Removable discontinuity (hole) at (1, 2).
Divide every term by x²: (3 - 5/x + 1/x²)/(2 + 1/x - 4/x²). As x→∞, all terms with x in denominator → 0. Limit = 3/2.

First: deg(num)=3 > deg(den)=2. Divide by x²: (5x+2/x)/(1-1/x²) → ∞. The limit is ∞ (no horizontal asymptote). Second: deg(num)=1 < deg(den)=3. Divide by x³: (1/x²+3/x³)/(1+1/x³) → 0. The limit is 0 (HA y=0).
